content:
Added the four cases from the forum: 
https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-ticket-to-ride-europe/2304/15?u=jbm

Had to explicitly set the diffiulty, so it's hereby changed from [void] to Very Hard (the category it already appeared in).

So I used the opportunity to set a tag: Classic board games.

Hello,

lovely puzzle, really needed to optimize a lot my solution to make it work.
Once overcome, I was curious to see the "official" solution from the creator.
It seems you had the same kind of idea as myself with the BestGrayResultantHand. But unfortunately this does not work for all cases. To validate my code, I created two tests :

Test 1:
in:
15 0 4
8 7 0 0 0 0 0 0 0
6 0 Gray city1 city2
4 0 Gray city3 city4
4 0 Gray city5 city6
1 0 Gray city7 city8
out:
30

Test 2:
in:
15 0 4
8 7 0 0 0 0 0 0 0
6 0 Gray city1 city2
4 0 Gray city3 city4
3 0 Gray city5 city6
2 0 Gray city7 city8
out:
28

And unfortunately yours fails on the second one.

Regards
In test case 16 "Multiple tickets", the first input line states there are 7 routes, but there are 8 routes below that. Should that be fixed? Thanks.
This morning I added a whole boatload of new tests designed to walk you through the complicated ruleset toward a working solution.

More minor changes today:

 - I slightly modified the input format
 - I added a new single-ticket test as the first case, so it would show up right under the problem statement.
 - I fixed a misspelled city name in the Multi-purpose test, which changed the resultant score.

I was playing around with this a bit today and was able to significantly speed up my code.  So I added another test and validator that are even more complex, to take advantage of the extra processing ability.
I have significantly updated the description. Hopefully it is more understandable now. I have also added the fact that incomplete tickets will deduct points from your score.

Rules difficult to understand. I think you should detail the example, and in the classic board game, when you don't achieve a ticket, you have negative point.
Great Puzzle

Hello, I have never played this game and it seems to be a very good puzzle. In my opinion is the goal bit long and and a bit hard to understand (I have not check the result for the moment). So I just rewrite here with a few changes. That is just a suggestion.

--

Ticket to Ride is a classic board game by Alan Moon and Days of Wonder in which you earn points by connecting cities via completed train routes. Based on this game, the goal of this puzzle is to calculate the maximum score that you can achieve. 

You will be provided information about the starting game state, including:
- Number of trainCars you are allowed to use
- Cards in your hand, each are showing 1 trainCar in a color or 1 engine. Each card can only be used one time.
- Tickets in your hand, each are showing two cities and how much bonus points you earn by connecting them (directly or not)
- Available routes on the board and conditions to complete them

Each route in the game has:
- A length, indicating how many trainCars are needed to complete the route.
- A color, indicating which color of cards are needed to complete the route.
- Two cities that will be connected once the route has been completed.

You get points for completing routes, according to this table for each route:
- lenght 1: 1 point
- lenght 2: 2 points
- lenght 3: 4 points
- lenght 4: 7 points
- lenght 6: 15 points
- lenght 8: 21 points

Each engine cards can replace 1 trainCard of any color. Gray routes can be completed with cards of any color, but all cards used for a Gray route must be the same color (potentially supplemented with engines).
For example, a Gray route of length 3 could be completed:
- with 3 pink cards,
- with 2 black cards and 1 engine,
- but not with 2 blue cards and 1 green card.

Some Gray routes require that one or more of the cards played on them must be an engine.
For example, a route of length 3 with requiredEngines equal to 1 could be completed:
- with 2 red cards and 1 engine,
- with 1 black and 2 engines,
- but not with 3 blue cards,
- and not with 1 green, 1 yellow, and 1 engine.

Global example with:
- a ticket awarding 5 bonus points for connecting Athina and Angora
- a route of length 2 between Athina and Smyrna,
- and a route of length 3 between Smyrna and Angora.
With these routes completed you get the 5 bonus points received for connecting (in 2 parts here) Athina to Angora + the 6 points (lenght 2: 2 points + lenght 3: 4 points) received for completing the two routes = 11 points.
Thanks for taking the time to write such detailed feedback. I really appreciate it. I hope to be able to overhaul this puzzle sometime within the next couple of weeks.
You're right! I forgot to incorporate negative points for tickets! I'll have to take that into account.

Ironically, the first version of the code I had that passed test 1 happened to pass the tests all the way through the last two pairs.
*Then* I needed to actually take a look at  complexity.

Anyway, solved, approving. Can't think of anything to complain about in the statement that weren't trivialities I could take care of myself.
Closest call was about the negative points for failed tickets; for a moment I thought that was all you were going to say, leaving it pretty ambiguous. But no, the precise count is there in the Scoring Tickets section.

I'm as impressed as ever by the amount of work you put into those validators.
You're absolutely right! Good catch. Thanks. I have updated it.
Huh! Very interesting. I'm not going to double-check now, but I assume you're right. Thanks for pointing it out!
And the author's code is too slow to pass again after the hardware change. So update postponed until someone can fix that (I don't know C#).
If you still want to update the puzzle I have a working solution in C# that passes the additional tests from the forum.
You're high-level enough to do it on your own, no?
Sure, I just didn't want to take that initiative from you.
You'll be fine :)
Thanks, JBM. I appreciate the time that you have taken to solve this puzzle. I'm pretty fond of it, and I very hope that it will eventually be published.
I have made some changes. Please take another look if you have the opportunity.
I have made some changes. Please take another look if you have the opportunity.

Hello, I have took a long time before answer to you. I find that the goal is now clear. So I accept.

I have just added the constraints if you agree. I have tried with a low level language and it's always better to know the limits of data (for size of arrays).
